Reading 1

Read the text and answer the questions that follow

Close Protection Qualification

RMP (Royal Military Police) personnel who volunteer for Close Protection (CP) training attend an eight-week basic course at the Close Protection Unit in Hampshire, UK. Personnel need to apply at least six months in advance as competition for places is high. Here personnel learn about all aspects of operational close protection. The training consists of training in specialist weapons and tactics including advanced marksmanship training, tactical convoy driving, unarmed combat skills, reconnaissance and counter and anti-surveillance techniques. The course focuses on developing highly trained, robust personnel capable of carrying out CP operations in various environments in both overt and covert roles. Volunteers for the course must pass the Army’s personal fitness assessment and then participate in a physical training program designed to develop fitness up to CP operational standards. Students validate their understanding of the training in a live protection exercise simulating a real protection scenario over several days.

You learn special soldiering skills for your role in close protection, you also develop strong communication skills as you need to speak to and assist senior officers and diplomats on a daily basis when you are deployed. You learn to work as part of a team and also on your own and to be responsible, dependable and quick thinking under pressure. At the conclusion of the eight-week course, successful students are assigned to a team for a further 4 weeks of theatre specific training. Close Protection is one of the many exciting opportunities in the RMP.
